greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = smallest integer that, upon multiplying any divisor of n, produces a member of A025487.
comment: Each member of A025487 appears infinitely often, and exactly once among odd values of n. a(m) = a(n) iff A000265(m) = A000265(n).
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..2370
formula: If n = Product p(i)^e(i), then a(n) = Product A002110(i-1)^e(i). Sequence is completely multiplicative.
example: For any divisor d of 6 (d = 1, 2, 3, 6), 2d (2, 4, 6, 12) is always a member of A025487. 2 is the smallest integer with this relationship to 6; therefore, a(6)=2.
program: def P(n): return reduce(mul, [i for i in primerange(2, n + 1)])
return 1 if n==1 else (reduce(mul, [P(i)**f[i] for i in f]))//n
print([a(n) for n in range(1, 101)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, May 14 2017
results.author: _Matthew Vandermast_, Nov 30 2010
